overview_metadata.overview_subtitle: Choosing a Function for a Model
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students play a game as a real-world situation to engage in the mathematical modeling process. They organize their game results in a table, use regression to predict the results for an advanced version of the game, test their prediction by playing the game, and make a mathematical conclusion. Students then generalize when a linear regression or exponential regression is more appropriate for a data set.

overview_item_data_items: I can model situations using linear and exponential functions.
I can determine the appropriate regression equation for a data set.
I can solve a complex problem using the mathematical modeling process.

Mathematical modeling involves noticing patterns and formulating mathematical questions, organizing information and representing it using appropriate mathematical notation, analyzing mathematical representations and using them to make predictions, and then testing these predictions and interpreting the results.
You can use both linear and exponential regression to model situations.
You can use regression equations to make predictions about real-world situations.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students play a game to move an entire stack of discs from the start circle to any of the other circles.
Students develop regression equations; predict outcomes; and validate predictions using game data.
Students explain how to determine whether a linear or exponential regression is more appropriate for a data set.
